title: A Simple Method for the Isolation and in vitro Expansion of Highly Pure Mouse and Human Satellite Cells
procedures: Isolation of muscle satellite cellsNotes:  Experimental procedures should be performed only after obtaining ethical approval. Follow the same procedure for both mouse and human muscle. Isolation of mouse satellite cells Day 1: Preparation prior to muscle dissectionPrepare 70% ethanol (see Recipe).Autoclave dissection instruments (scissors and tweezers).Add 3 ml of DMEM supplemented with 1% pen/strep into 60 mm cell culture dishes (one dish/mouse or one dish per gram of human muscle biopsy). These will be used to collect the dissected muscle.Coat the cell culture dishes with 0.1% gelatin:Coat 35 mm and 100 mm cell culture dishes with 1 ml and 5 ml of 0.1% gelatin, respectively, ensuring that the entire surface of the dish is evenly coated, and incubate for 30 min in a cell incubator at 37°C with 5% CO2. Next, remove excess gelatin (without washing the dishes), and leave the dishes open to air dry for 10-15 min under the hood. These dishes will be used for cell culture.Note: The 35 mm dishes will be needed one day following isolation. Prepare collagenase type II and collagenase/dispase digestion solutions (see Recipes).Prepare enzyme neutralization buffer (see Recipes).Prepare cell growth medium (see Recipes).Prepare cell differentiation medium (see Recipes).Sterilize a scalpel and surgical blades.Pre-warm a water bath at 37°C.Day 1: Dissection of mouse hindlimb musclesFor a schematic representation of the dissection process, see Figure 2.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e4238/bioprotoc-11-23-4238-g002.jpgFigure 2. Dissection of mouse quadriceps, tibialis anterior, and gastrocnemius muscles. Euthanize a mouse [i.e., by cervical dislocation;           Benedetti et al. (2021)].Pin the mouse to a dissection board and spray it with 70% ethanol.Using dissection scissors, make an incision on the skin above the ankle, and peel off the skin over the entire length of the hindlimbs to expose the muscles below.Collect the tibialis anterior, quadriceps, and gastrocnemius muscles from both legs (Figure 2).

Place the dissected muscles in a 60 mm dish containing DMEM supplemented with 1% pen/strep, and remove any hair to minimize the risk of contamination.Transfer the dishes under a biosafety cabinet and finely cut up the muscles into 1 mm pieces using a sterile scalpel (Figure 1b).Note: Remove and discard any fat from the dissected muscle. Transfer the minced muscles into a 50 ml tube and centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at room temperature (RT).Day 1: Muscle digestion I (Figure 1c).Aspirate the supernatant with a 10 ml serological pipette and resuspend the minced muscles in 10 ml of collagenase type II digestion solution per gram of tissue (see Recipes).Note: It is important to use a pipette to remove the supernatant, as the pellet is not stable in this step. Seal the tubes with parafilm and transfer them to a shaking (100 rpm) pre-warmed (37°C) water bath for 45 min.Note: Position the tubes horizontally so that they are completely submerged in water. Spray the tubes with 70% ethanol and transfer them to a biosafety cabinet.Block the digestion enzyme by adding 10 ml of enzyme neutralization buffer per gram of tissue (see Recipes).Pipette up and down with a 10 ml serological pipette five times.Centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at RT.Day 1: Muscle digestion II (Figure 1d).Aspirate the supernatant with a 10 ml serological pipette and resuspend the pellet in 10 ml of collagenase/dispase digestion solution per gram of tissue (see Recipes).Seal the tubes with parafilm and transfer them into a shaking (100 rpm) pre-warmed (37°C) water bath (as in Step A3b) for 30 min.Spray the tubes with 70% ethanol and transfer them to a biosafety cabinet.Block the digestion by adding 10 ml of enzyme neutralization buffer per gram of tissue (see Recipes).

Pipette up and down with a 10 ml serological pipette five times.Sieve the digested muscles through a 70 µm cell strainer into a new 50 ml tube.Sieve the digested muscles through a 40 µm cell strainer into a new 50 ml tube.Note: An adequately digested muscle will pass through the strainers easily. If necessary, the muscle digest can be passed again through another strainer to get rid of most of the cell debris and undigested muscle. Centrifuge the tube with muscle digest at 300 × g for 5 min at RT.Discard the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 10 ml of DMEM 10% FBS. Count the number of muscle mononuclear cells using trypan blue. Note: At this step, you can combine the pellets if more than 1 mouse was used. On average, the number of cells released after digestion from 3, 4-8-weeks-old mice is around 107 cells.  Day 1: Pre-plating step (Figure 1e-1f).Plate the cells at 105/ml in a 100 mm dish (uncoated) in 20 ml of DMEM 10% FBS 1% pen/strep and incubate at 37°C for 1 h.Collect the non-adhered cells in a 50 ml tube and centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at RT.Discard the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet in DMEM 10% FBS 1% pen/strep.Count the resuspended cells and plate them at 105/ml into a 100 mm dish (uncoated) in 20 ml of DMEM 10% FBS 1% pen/strep. Incubate the cells at 37°C for 1 h (as in Step A5a).Collect and transfer the non-adhered cells into a 50 ml tube.Note: On average, the pre-plating steps remove around 50% of strongly adherent cells such as fibroblasts. Centrifuge the tube with non-adhered cells at 300 × g for 5 min at RT.Discard the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet in growth medium (see Recipes).

Plate the cells into 0.1% gelatin coated 100 mm dishes at 106 cells/dish. Grow them overnight (Figure 1g).Day 2: Ice-cold treatment (ICT) (Figure 1h).Wash the dishes containing the heterogeneous mix of adhered muscle cells three times with 10 ml of PBS (with MgCl2 and CaCl2) at RT.Note: Gently pipette PBS all around the dish. Add 10 ml of ice-cold PBS (without MgCl2 and CaCl2) to each 100 mm dish. Note: Both PBS with or without CaCl2 can be used. However, using PBS without CaCl2 will facilitate detachment.  Fill a polystyrene box with ice (0°C) and place the dishes on top of the ice for 15-30 min with occasional gentle manual shaking of the dish (creating a swirling motion).Notes:  If purity is of utmost importance (e.g., 99-100% purity), the dishes should not be kept on ice for longer than 30 min. Nevertheless, the dishes can be kept on ice for up to 1 h to increase cell yield, with purity still high at 90%. The original dishes (from day 1 of the isolation procedure) containing heterogeneous muscle cells can be kept up to day 3 of culture and used for further rounds of ICTs . Collect the detached cells into a 50 ml tube.Wash the original dish once more with 10 ml of PBS to collect the remaining detached cells.Note: Gently pipette PBS all around the dish. Centrifuge the cells at 300 × g for 5 min at RT.Discard the supernatant and resuspend the cells in growth medium.Count the cells. Note: On average, 1.5 × 104-2 × 104 SCs can be collected after 30 min on ice at 24 h of culture of the original dish. A further 4 × 104 SCs can be collected after the second or third ICT at 48 h or 72 h of culture).

Plate the cells into 35 mm dishes precoated with 0.1% gelatin, at a density of 103 cells/dish and place them into a cell incubator.Note: At this density, the SC proliferate for up to three days. Afterward, they begin to differentiate. Increasing the plating density will accelerate the time it takes for the myoblasts to differentiate and fuse into myotubes. Cell cultureCulture the cells in growth medium, changing the medium every two days.To induce myoblast differentiation, remove growth medium and replace it with differentiation medium (see Recipes) once the cells reach 80% confluency.Cell passagingPlace the dishes containing proliferating SCs on ice for up to 30 min.Follow the steps described in A6.Isolation of human muscle satellite cells Notes:  Experimental procedures using human muscle biopsies should be performed only after obtaining ethical approval and informed consent. The number of SCs obtained from human muscle biopsies may vary depending on the age of the donor, with a smaller number of cells typically obtained from older donors. Preparation prior to muscle dissectionProceed as in Step A1.Muscle cuttingPlace the human muscle biopsy in a 60 mm dish containing DMEM supplemented with 1% pen/strep. Work in a biosafety cabinet.Remove any fat and connective tissue using scissors.Finely cut up the muscle into 1 mm pieces using a sterile scalpel.Transfer the minced muscles to a 50 ml tube and centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min.Muscle digestion I:Proceed as described in A3.Muscle digestion II:Proceed as described in A4. Note: On average, 2 × 106 muscle mononuclear cells can be obtained from digestion of 1 g of human muscle biopsy.  Pre-plating:Proceed as in A5.ICT:Proceed as in A6.

To further enrich in SCs the heterogeneous muscle cell culture on day 1 after isolation, it may be necessary to grow it for an additional 3-4 days before proceeding to ICT (when the culture reaches a confluency of about 80%).Notes:   On average, 1 × 104 SCs can be collected after the first ICT.   A further 2 × 104 SCs can be collected after the second or third ICT at 48 h or 72 h of culture.  Cell cultureProceed as in Step A7.Note: Human SCs proliferate slower than mouse SCs, with a doubling time of 46 h. Analysis of mouse and human satellite cell specific marker expression by immunofluorescence stainingGrow the cells in a 35 mm dish.Aspirate the medium and wash the dishes once with 1 ml of PBS with MgCl2 and CaCl2.Fix the cells by adding 4% PFA (1 ml/35 mm dish) and incubate for 10 min at room temperature.Note: PFA is toxic and must be used under a chemical fume hood. Discard the PFA into a toxic waste container and wash three times with 1 ml of PBS for 5 min each.Permeabilize the cells by adding cold methanol (1 ml/35 mm dish) and incubate at -20°C for 6 min.Discard the methanol into a toxic waste container and wash three times with 1 ml of PBS for 5 min each.Remove the PBS and mark the border of the dish with a hydrophobic pen.Block by adding PBS containing 5% goat serum (100 μl/35 mm dish) for 30 min at RT.Remove the blocking solution and incubate the cells with the primary antibodies (100 μl/35 mm dish) at the appropriate dilution [Pax7 (1:10), MyoD (1:50), Myogenin (1:20), and Myosin Heavy Chain (1:20) diluted in sterile filtered 4% BSA/PBS] overnight in a humidified chamber at 4°C.

Remove the primary antibody solution and wash three times with 1 ml of PBS for 5 min each.Incubate the cells with the secondary antibodies (100 μl/35 mm dish) [goat anti-rabbit Alexa Fluor 488 (1:1,000) and goat anti-mouse Alexa Fluor 555 (1:1,000) diluted in sterile filtered 1%BSA/PBS] for 1h at room temperature in a humified chamber in the dark.Remove the secondary antibody solution and wash three times with 1 ml of PBS for 5 min each.Counterstain the nuclei with Hoechst solution (see Recipes) (100 μl/35 mm dish) for 5 min at room temperature in the dark.Remove the Hoechst solution and wash three times with 1 ml of PBS for 5 min each.Mount the coverslips with Vectashield mounting medium (30 μl/35 mm dish).Analyze under a fluorescence microscope.
